column2: found between the border of Ethiopia and Kenya
column3: the administrative center for two woredas; Moyale of Somali Region and Moyale Oromia in Ethiopia.

column1: Moyale is the main border post on the Nairobi-Addis Ababa road
column2: lying north of the Dide Galgalu Desert. It is known for its traditional architecture.

column1: An early settler at Moyale was a Greek by the name of Zaphiro
column2: who had a station which he had named "Fort Harrington". When C.W. Gwynn visited in 1908
column3: Zaphiro's station consisted of a garden that covered several acres and his house
column4: located on a spur projecting from the Boran highlands
column5: and providing access through the line of cliffs that run along the border. "This route may well become some day a considerable trade artery
column6: Gwynn predicted. Fort Harrington is therefore well placed as a healthy administrative post and as a possible commercial centre."During World War II
column7: both parts of the town were captured by Italians from Ethiopia in 1940
column8: and retaken by the British on 15 July 1941.

column1: Tensions rose in the Kenyan side of Moyale in early 1999
column2: after an Imam was shot dead during an Ethiopian raid across the Ethiopian-Kenyan border in pursuit of rebels of the Oromo Liberation Front (OLF). The Kenyan residents of the town
column4: which they attributed to Ethiopian security men who believed he was a sympathizer of the OLF. In March 2018
column5: nine civilians were killed by the Ethiopian National Defense Force near Moyale after being misidentified as Oromo Liberation Front militants.In November 2009
column6: Ethiopian Prime Minister Meles Zenawi announced plans to extend the Ethiopian railroad to Moyale. This would facilitate Kenyan plans
column7: which at the time were at an advanced stage
column8: to develop the port of Lamu and connect it to the Kenyan side of Moyale with a tarmac road.This business town is disputed between the two dominant ethnic groups who are Oromos and Somalis. Moyale saw four days of ethnic clashes in July 2012 over a long-standing land dispute between Borana and Garre communities
column9: exacerbated by drought conditions. The fighting left at least eighteen dead
column10: and more than twenty thousand people fled across the border into Kenya.
